qa_pairs.question: What was the role of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2019, in finalizing the FY2019 federal budget, and when was it passed?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2019, played a key role in finalizing the FY2019 federal budget by incorporating the remaining appropriations bills, ensuring full government funding after a partial shutdown. The Act was passed on February 15, 2019, marking the final step in enacting the fiscal year 2019 budget.<cite>[S31]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] 2019 United States federal budget


# 2019 United States federal budget



The United States federal budget for fiscal year 2019 ran from October 1, 2018, to September 30, 2019. [S2] Five appropriation bills were passed in September 2018, the first time five bills had been enacted on time in 22 years, with the rest of the government being funded through a series of three continuing resolutions. [S3] A gap between the second and third of these led to the 2018–19 federal government shutdown. [S4] The remainder of government funding was enacted as an omnibus spending bill in February 2019. [S5] ## Budget

The FY2019 budget was subject to the spending caps of the Budget Control Act of 2011, as modified by the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018. [S6] ## Related fiscal legislation


### Initial appropriations legislation

The 115th United States Congress initially proposed three "minibus" appropriations bills prior to the beginning of the fiscal year. [S7] Two of these were enacted prior to the beginning of the fiscal year, accounting for five bills totaling 77% of federal discretionary funding, and including a continuing resolution until December 7 for the remaining agencies. [S8] It was the first time five bills had been enacted on time in 22 years, since the 1997 fiscal year. [S9] The two bills are:

* The Energy and Water, Legislative Branch, and Military Construction and Veterans Affairs Appropriations Act, 2019 (H.R. [S10] 5895) was enacted on September 21, 2018. [S11] * The Department of Defense and Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education Appropriations Act, 2019 and Continuing Appropriations Act, 2019 (H.R. [S12] 6157) was enacted on September 28, 2018. [S13] On December 6, Congress passed a second continuing resolution (H.J.Res. [S14] 143) lasting through December 21, to give more time for negotiations on Trump's proposed border wall, which had been delayed due to the death and funeral of George H. [S15] W. [S16] Bush. [S17] ### Government shutdown

On December 19, the Senate passed a second continuing resolution, the Further Additional Continuing Appropriations Act, 2019 (H.R. [S18] 695), lasting until February 8, 2019. [S19] However, after Trump declared the following day that he would not sign any funding bill that did not include border wall funding, the House passed a version of the continuing resolution on December 20 that added $5 billion for the wall and $8 billion in disaster aid. [S20] Negotiations in the Senate did not lead to passage of a continuing resolution that day, causing a government shutdown to begin on December 22. [S21] On January 3, 2019, the first day of the 116th Congress, the House passed a continuing resolution for the Department of Homeland Security (H.J.Res. [S22] 1) on a vote of 239–192, as well as a separate bill funding the remainder of government agencies, the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2019 (H.R. [S23] 21), on a vote of 241–190. [S24] The bills were not immediately expected to be considered in the Senate. [S25] Beginning on January 9, the House was expected to vote on four of the appropriations bills individually: Treasury and the General Services Administration; Agriculture and the Food and Drug Administration; Interior and the Environmental Protection Agency; and Transportation and Housing and Urban Development. [S26] This strategy has been compared to one used by Republicans during the 2013 shutdown in the form of a series of fourteen mini-continuing resolutions. [S27] The government shutdown was ended by the passage of the Further Additional Continuing Appropriations Act, 2019 (H.J.Res. [S28] 28) on January 25. [S29] ### Final appropriations legislation

The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2019 (H.J.Res. [S30] 31) incorporated the remaining appropriations bills and was passed on February 15. [S31] ## Total revenue


### Receipts

Receipts by source: *(in billions of dollars)*

Passage 2:
[S32] | Source | Requested | Actual |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Individual income tax | $1,687.7 | $1,717.9 |
| Corporate income tax | $225.3 | $230.2 |
| Social Security and other payroll tax | $1,237.6 | $1,243.1 |
| Excise tax | $108.4 | $98.9 |
| Estate and gift taxes | $16.8 | $16.7 |
| Customs duties | $43.9 | $70.8 |
| Other miscellaneous receipts | $102.5 | $85.8 |
| **Total** | **$3,422.3** | **$3,463.4** |
chunk_list:
[S1] 2019 United States federal budget


# 2019 United States federal budget



The United States federal budget for fiscal year 2019 ran from October 1, 2018, to September 30, 2019. [S2] Five appropriation bills were passed in September 2018, the first time five bills had been enacted on time in 22 years, with the rest of the government being funded through a series of three continuing resolutions. [S3] A gap between the second and third of these led to the 2018–19 federal government shutdown. [S4] The remainder of government funding was enacted as an omnibus spending bill in February 2019. [S5] ## Budget

The FY2019 budget was subject to the spending caps of the Budget Control Act of 2011, as modified by the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018. [S6] ## Related fiscal legislation


### Initial appropriations legislation

The 115th United States Congress initially proposed three "minibus" appropriations bills prior to the beginning of the fiscal year. [S7] Two of these were enacted prior to the beginning of the fiscal year, accounting for five bills totaling 77% of federal discretionary funding, and including a continuing resolution until December 7 for the remaining agencies. [S8] It was the first time five bills had been enacted on time in 22 years, since the 1997 fiscal year. [S9] The two bills are:

* The Energy and Water, Legislative Branch, and Military Construction and Veterans Affairs Appropriations Act, 2019 (H.R. [S10] 5895) was enacted on September 21, 2018. [S11] * The Department of Defense and Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education Appropriations Act, 2019 and Continuing Appropriations Act, 2019 (H.R. [S12] 6157) was enacted on September 28, 2018. [S13] On December 6, Congress passed a second continuing resolution (H.J.Res. [S14] 143) lasting through December 21, to give more time for negotiations on Trump's proposed border wall, which had been delayed due to the death and funeral of George H. [S15] W. [S16] Bush. [S17] ### Government shutdown

On December 19, the Senate passed a second continuing resolution, the Further Additional Continuing Appropriations Act, 2019 (H.R. [S18] 695), lasting until February 8, 2019. [S19] However, after Trump declared the following day that he would not sign any funding bill that did not include border wall funding, the House passed a version of the continuing resolution on December 20 that added $5 billion for the wall and $8 billion in disaster aid. [S20] Negotiations in the Senate did not lead to passage of a continuing resolution that day, causing a government shutdown to begin on December 22. [S21] On January 3, 2019, the first day of the 116th Congress, the House passed a continuing resolution for the Department of Homeland Security (H.J.Res. [S22] 1) on a vote of 239–192, as well as a separate bill funding the remainder of government agencies, the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2019 (H.R. [S23] 21), on a vote of 241–190. [S24] The bills were not immediately expected to be considered in the Senate. [S25] Beginning on January 9, the House was expected to vote on four of the appropriations bills individually: Treasury and the General Services Administration; Agriculture and the Food and Drug Administration; Interior and the Environmental Protection Agency; and Transportation and Housing and Urban Development. [S26] This strategy has been compared to one used by Republicans during the 2013 shutdown in the form of a series of fourteen mini-continuing resolutions. [S27] The government shutdown was ended by the passage of the Further Additional Continuing Appropriations Act, 2019 (H.J.Res. [S28] 28) on January 25. [S29] ### Final appropriations legislation

The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2019 (H.J.Res. [S30] 31) incorporated the remaining appropriations bills and was passed on February 15. [S31] ## Total revenue


### Receipts

Receipts by source: *(in billions of dollars)*

[S32] | Source | Requested | Actual |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Individual income tax | $1,687.7 | $1,717.9 |
| Corporate income tax | $225.3 | $230.2 |
| Social Security and other payroll tax | $1,237.6 | $1,243.1 |
| Excise tax | $108.4 | $98.9 |
| Estate and gift taxes | $16.8 | $16.7 |
| Customs duties | $43.9 | $70.8 |
| Other miscellaneous receipts | $102.5 | $85.8 |
| **Total** | **$3,422.3** | **$3,463.4** |

So the role was to incorporate the remaining appropriations bills, thereby finalizing the funding for the government. The date passed is February 15, as per [S31]. However, there's also a mention in [S23] of the act being passed on January 3, 2019. But that might be an earlier version or a different part of the process. The key is that the final passage was on February 15. 

Also, in the "Government shutdown" section, on January 3, 2019, the House passed the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2019 (H.R. 21), but it wasn't immediately considered in the Senate. Then later, the Further Additional Continuing Appropriations Act was passed on January 25 to end the shutdown. Then the final Consolidated Appropriations Act was passed on February 15. So the role of the Act was to finalize the appropriations after the shutdown, incorporating the remaining bills. 

Therefore, the answer should state that the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2019, was passed on February 15, 2019, and it incorporated the remaining appropriations bills to finalize the FY2019 budget. The citations would be [S31] for the date and role. Also, [S23] mentions the act being passed on January 3, but that might be part of the process leading up to the final passage. However, the question is about finalizing the budget, so the key date is February 15. The user might need to know that the act was passed on February 15, and that it incorporated the remaining bills. So the citations would be [S31] for the date and role. Also, maybe [S23] if the act was passed earlier, but the final passage is February 15. Need to check the exact wording.

The passage says: "The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2019 (H.J.Res. [S30] 31) incorporated the remaining appropriations bills and was passed on February 15." So the key sentence is [S31]. Therefore, the answer should cite [S31] for both the role and the date. The other mention of H.R. 21 on January 3 is part of the process but not the final passage. So the answer is based on [S31].

qa_pairs.question: What were the main sources of federal revenue in FY2019, and what was the total actual revenue according to the provided data?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The main sources of federal revenue in FY2019 included individual income tax, corporate income tax, social security and other payroll tax, excise tax, estate and gift taxes, customs duties, and other miscellaneous receipts, as detailed in the provided table. The total actual federal revenue for FY2019 was $3,463.4 billion, according to the data in the table.<cite>[S32]</cite></statement>
